Virginia â€œGinniâ€ Thomas, the wife of Supreme Court Justice Clarence Thomas, has agreed to be interviewed by the House select committee investigating the events of Jan. 6, 2021, sometime in the coming weeks.

The news was first reported by CNN correspondent Jamie Gangel and then later by MSNBCâ€™s Ali Vitali, who said Thomas responded to a letter asking her to appear before the committee and was not subpoenaed.

Thomasâ€™ involvement in former President Donald Trumpâ€™s â€œstolen electionâ€ lies and the U.S. Capitol riot has been a subject of interest for a while, especially since there is evidence she urged at least two Wisconsin state lawmakers, including the chair of the Senate elections committee, to overturn President Joe Bidenâ€™s 2020 election win.

She also reportedly sent messages to more than two dozen lawmakers in Arizona, arguing, without evidence, that there had been widespread election fraud in the 2020 presidential election.

In addition, there are texts in which Thomas urged then-White House chief of staff Mark Meadows to continue the battle to overturn election results, as well as texts and emails to Trump ally attorney and â€œcoup memoâ€ author John Eastman discussing how to upend the vote.

â€œHelp This Great President stand firm, Mark,â€ Thomas wrote Meadows after the 2020 election. â€œThe majority knows Biden and the Left is attempting the greatest Heist of our History.â€

Thomas had turned down other requests to appear before the House panel.

In June, her attorney Mark Paoletta said that there was no reason for her to testify before the House select committee and said he had â€œserious concernsâ€ about any potential interview.

No date has been announced for Thomasâ€™ interview with the committee, which will hold its next hearing Sept. 28.

â€œWe inherit our familyâ€™s dreams, but also their fears. It takes a lot of courage to make your own path.â€

That line of narration from the new documentary â€œMijaâ€ â€” spoken by one of its subjects, musician and music manager Doris MuÃ±oz â€” has stuck with me for months since its Sundance Film Festival premiere in January.

The documentary follows MuÃ±oz and two of her clients: first, singer/songwriter Cuco and later, singer/songwriter Jacks Haupt. MuÃ±ozâ€™s success as a manager representing fellow Latinx artists has provided material support to her family. In the film, her parents are undergoing the arduous and bureaucratic process of applying for green cards. MuÃ±oz, the only U.S.-born member of her immediate family, is also the liaison between them and her brother, who lives across the border in Tijuana after he was deported.

In â€œMija,â€ MuÃ±oz and Haupt grapple with a lot of complicated feelings that are familiar to many children of immigrants, especially those trying to make it in a creative profession. They want to live up to their parentsâ€™ expectations and make them proud, and feel obligated to help them and honor their enormous sacrifices. Amid all of that, theyâ€™re figuring out how to make it in a field where there arenâ€™t a lot of people like them.

Premiering Friday on Disney+, â€œMijaâ€ is the feature debut of director Isabel Castro. She previously spent a decade in journalism, producing documentary shorts and series at the New York Times, the Marshall Project and VICE, where she was an Emmy-nominated producer for â€œVICE News Tonight.â€ As she explained in an interview, the seed for â€œMijaâ€ came from a desire to tell more nuanced stories about immigration â€” not just about the act of immigrating or the policies behind it, but the complex emotions it brings up and â€œthe ripple effects across different generations.â€

Advertisement
Isabel Castro, the director of "Mija."
Isabel Castro, the director of "Mija."Jackie Russo
â€œThe range of emotions that comes along with immigrating to this country is really, really nuanced and complicated, and the spectrum is really wide,â€ she said. â€œOftentimes, immigrant stories are very narrowly focused on exclusively the trauma of that experience.â€

Itâ€™s the kind of story Castro has wanted to tell for many years, and the intersection of several of her creative goals. As a Mexican American journalist covering immigration and civil rights in the Trump era, Castro â€œstarted to feel really disillusioned by the kind of aspirations towards objectivity,â€ she said. â€œJust looking at the ways that different government policies were affecting folks on the ground, it was very difficult for me to really try to maintain objectivity.â€

Advertisement
Castro, who has a background in filmmaking but cut her teeth in journalism and documentary TV work to build a more steady career path, quit her day job and used her savings to get back into independent film. She took a course in cinematography to be able to work independently and reduce costs, since getting a film funded can be a long and cumbersome process.

When considering what story she wanted to tell, she remembered that â€œIâ€™ve always loved music docs. So I thought, â€˜Oh, maybe thereâ€™s a way to have a music doc intersect with a story about immigration,â€™â€ she said. â€œAnd thatâ€™s kind of the seed that was planted.â€

In 2019, Castro came across a California Sunday magazine profile about Cuco, which mentioned the work MuÃ±oz was doing as his manager. After several phone conversations with MuÃ±oz, Castro met her in person later that year at â€œSelena for Sanctuary,â€ a concert paying homage to the late singer and icon Selena. A few years earlier, MuÃ±oz began the event as a way to raise money for her parentsâ€™ legal fees, and later grew it into a fundraiser for immigrant rights organizations. Soon after the two met, MuÃ±oz agreed to be part of the documentary.

Advertisement
Doris MuÃ±oz and Jacks Haupt lay on a multicolored blanket in the grass, in a scene from the documentary "Mija."
Doris MuÃ±oz and Jacks Haupt lay on a multicolored blanket in the grass, in a scene from the documentary "Mija."Disney
When deciding to move away from journalism and make her own feature film, Castro also wanted to be able to make more specific stylistic choices. â€œThereâ€™s objectivity, also, in the vernacular of imagery that journalism is told in. And I wanted to make something that felt really subjective, that felt really intentional about its POV and about the image itself being part of the messaging and the story,â€ she said.

For instance, â€œMijaâ€ features a vibrant color palette and dream-like sequences, which were inspired by HBOâ€™s â€œEuphoria.â€ â€œIn terms of trying to react to or deviate from the typical ways that immigrant stories are told, I really wanted to adopt a visual language that felt really young and exciting, and so I looked a lot to â€˜Euphoria,â€™â€ she said.

Advertisement
In choosing to have MuÃ±oz narrate the documentary, Castro drew from the voiceover of characters like Cher Horowitz in â€œCluelessâ€ and Carrie Bradshaw in â€œSex and the City,â€ which she loved as a teen. â€œI really connected to Carrie and Cher, despite our huge differences, just because of the VO. I felt like there was an intimacy that was established through the voiceover,â€ she said. â€œSo I always knew that I wanted to emulate that in the voiceover for the film.â€

Like everything else in the world, the pandemic shifted MuÃ±ozâ€™s life and the course of the documentary, forcing Castro to get creative with the production limitations. â€œI went into this thinking it would be a more traditional music doc. I thought Iâ€™d be on the road. I thought it was going to be a Chicano â€˜Almost Famous,â€™â€ she said. â€œBut the pandemic hit, and my expectations just completely went out the window.â€

While we didnâ€™t get that road movie version of â€œMija,â€ the filmâ€™s intimate moments of reflection lend itself well to the complicated questions it explores â€” the kind that donâ€™t fit into a pithy headline or neat narrative.

Advertisement
For children of immigrants, in some ways, perhaps the ultimate gift to our parents is to get to make the choices they couldnâ€™t, and to be able to move beyond basic questions of survival and material needs. But it also can be hard for our parents to understand our choices, and we can feel a sense of guilt for being able to focus on less material concerns than they did.

â€œOne of the emotions that I personally carry with me and most wanted to explore in this was the feeling of guilt,â€ Castro said. â€œAnd I think that thatâ€™s particularly prevalent in the stories of immigrants because migration just is inherently a traumatic experience. No matter what your story is, itâ€™s a decision to leave your home, and itâ€™s a decision to leave your country and your culture and move to a new place. And itâ€™s painful.â€

â€œAnd I think that as children of immigrants, oftentimes you see that pain or interpret that pain, and you want to honor it,â€ she continued. â€œAnd sometimes, that comes along with a lot of pressure, and that pressure often comes along with feelings of guilt. So I wanted to explore those kinds of emotions. I wanted the film to live not just exclusively in the trauma of immigration, because thatâ€™s always going to be there in our lives, in our stories and in our day-to-day experiences.â€

Advertisement
Castro wants more immigration stories to capture these more complicated feelings and questions.

â€œThe nuanced emotions are the ones that I think come up more often on a day-to-day basis,â€ she continued. â€œHaving covered immigration for many, many years, that is the reality of most peopleâ€™s experiences that I see. Itâ€™s not something black and white.â€

â€œMijaâ€ premieres Friday on Disney+.

A white woman who said that she was unfairly fired and branded a racist by her former employer after calling the cops on a Black bird-watcher in a New York park â€• leading social media users to dub her â€œCentral Park Karenâ€ â€• has had a discrimination lawsuit thrown out.

U.S. District Judge Ronnie Abrams on Wednesday dismissed the suit filed by Amy Cooper against investment firm Franklin Templeton, determining that her allegations of discrimination on the basis of race and sex â€” as well as defamation, negligence and intentional infliction of emotional distress â€” were unsubstantiated.

â€œWe are pleased that the court has dismissed the lawsuit. We continue to believe the company responded appropriately,â€ a representative for Franklin Templeton said in a statement to HuffPost.

The company announced Cooperâ€™s termination on social media shortly after video of her May 2020 encounter with a man named Christian Cooper â€• with whom she shares no relation â€• went viral. He had asked her to leash her dog in the park, prompting the woman to call 911 and accuse the bird-watcher of threatening her.

Amy Cooper is shown with her dog in a viral video from May 2020.
Amy Cooper is shown with her dog in a viral video from May 2020.via Associated Press
Advertisement
â€œIâ€™m going to tell them thereâ€™s an African American man threatening my life,â€ she said in the video.

Prosecutors, who charged her with filing a false report, said that Cooper also made a second 911 call in which she claimed that a Black man â€œtried to assault her in the Ramble area of the park.â€ A judge last year agreed to drop the criminal charge against her after she completed five sessions of an educational program that included instruction about racial bias.

Franklin Templeton quickly placed Cooper on administrative leave over the incident, before tweeting that the company had fired her after an internal review.

â€œWe do not tolerate racism of any kind at Franklin Templeton,â€ it said at the time.

Cooperâ€™s lawsuit accused the company of making defamatory statements against her in that tweet and claimed that an internal investigation was not performed.

Advertisement
Amy Cooper calls police in the viral video.
Amy Cooper calls police in the viral video.via Associated Press
However, Abrams ruled that merely watching video of the incident and holding a discussion within the company would â€œmeet a reasonable interpretation of â€˜internal review.â€™â€

â€œPlaintiff may take issue with the sufficiency of Defendantsâ€™ investigation into the incident, but she has not plausibly alleged that no investigation was conducted at all,â€ the judge said this week.

Advertisement
If someone inferred that the company was calling Cooper a racist in its tweet, that would constitute â€œprotected opinion,â€ according to Abrams.

â€œIt is well-established that an accusation of bigotry is a protected statement of opinion, rather than a defamatory statement of fact capable of being proven true or false,â€ she said.

An attorney for Cooper did not immediately respond to HuffPostâ€™s request for comment Thursday.

A volatile passenger has been charged with a federal crime â€” and banned for life from American Airlines â€” after he was captured on video punching a flight attendant in the head, according to Justice Department and airline officials.


The incident occurred Wednesday on a flight from San JosÃ© del Cabo in Mexico to Los Angeles.

Alexander Tung Cuu Le, 33, of Westminster, in Southern California, was arrested when the aircraft landed at Los Angeles International Airport, according to an American Airlines official. He was charged Thursday with one count of interference with flight crew members and attendants, which carries a maximum penalty of up to 20 years in prison, said a statement by the U.S. Attorneyâ€™s Office for the Central District of California.


According to the statement, Le grabbed a flight attendantâ€™s shoulder and demanded coffee about 20 minutes after the aircraft took off. He also allegedly disrupted passengers by hanging out near the first-class section of the cabin.


When another flight attendant told Le to return to his assigned seat, Le â€œallegedly stood up and assumed a fighting stance towards the flight attendant by making closed fists with both of his hands, which the flight attendant interpreted as a threat,â€ according to the DOJ statement.


A video taken by fellow passenger Barrie Livingstone shows Le apparently initially swinging his arm at the flight attendant but missing. As the attendant turned to walk away, Le can be seen rushing forward to strike the attendant in the head, eliciting cries of concern and outrage on the aircraft. The attack was â€œwitnessed by several passengers,â€ the Justice Department said.


Le then â€œfledâ€ to the back of the plane, where he was â€œapprehended by several passengersâ€ and crew members, the statement added.


Leâ€™s â€œhands and legs were cuffed,â€ but he â€œcontinuously unbuckled his seatbelt, causing flight attendants to restrain him to the seat with seatbelt extenders,â€ officials noted.


Le has been barred from all future flights by American Airlines.


â€œActs of violence against our team members are not tolerated by American Airlines,â€ said a statement from American. â€œThe individual involved in this incident will never be allowed to travel with us in the future, and we will work closely with law enforcement in their investigation.â€


The airline thanked crew members and passengers for restraining Le until the aircraft was met by law enforcement at LAX.


Le appeared Thursday at the U.S. District Court in downtown Los Angeles, where he was charged.


The hearing was continued to Monday, Ciaran McEvoy, a spokesperson for the U.S. attorneyâ€™s office, told SFGate. â€œThat will be a detention hearing to determine his bond, if any. Mr. Le has not pleaded to anything yet,â€ McEvoy added.


Attacks on flight attendants have skyrocketed in the last two years, largely triggered by sometimes violent, defiant responses to requirements to wear masks earlier in the COVID-19 pandemic. The Federal Aviation Administration logged an incredible 5,981 â€œunruly passenger reports last year. In 2020, the FAA investigated only 183 reports.

CAGUAS, Puerto Rico (AP) â€” More than a half million people in Puerto Rico remained without water service three days after Hurricane Fiona slammed into the U.S. territory, and many spent hours in lines Wednesday to fill jugs from water trucks while others scooped water from mountain runoff.

Sweat rolled down the faces of people in a long line of cars in the northern mountain town of Caguas, where the government had sent a water truck, one of at least 18 so-called â€œoasesâ€ set up across the island.

The situation was maddening for many people across an island once again left without basic services following a storm.

â€œWe thought we had a bad experience with Maria, but this was worse,â€ Gerardo RodrÃ­guez said in the southern coastal town of Salinas, referring to the 2017 hurricane that caused nearly 3,000 deaths and demolished the islandâ€™s power grid.

Fiona dumped roughly two feet of rain on parts of Puerto Rico before blasting across the eastern Dominican Republic and the Turks and Caicos Islands.

Advertisement
Swelled to Category 4 force, the storm was on a track to pass close by Bermuda early Friday and then hit easternmost Canada early Saturay, according to the U.S. National Hurricane Center.

The storm played havoc with Puerto Ricoâ€™s electrical grid, which had been patched but never fully rebuilt after Maria caused a blackout that lasted 11 months in some places.

A man points to a home that was collapsed by Hurricane Fiona at Villa Esperanza in Salinas, Puerto Rico, Wednesday, September 21, 2022.
A man points to a home that was collapsed by Hurricane Fiona at Villa Esperanza in Salinas, Puerto Rico, Wednesday, September 21, 2022.Alejandro Granadillo via Associated Press
Advertisement
As of Wednesday afternoon, roughly 70% of Puerto Rican customers lacked electricity, according to government figures.

In Caguas, the air conditioning of Emayra Veguillaâ€™s car wasnâ€™t working, so the bus driver propped up a small fan in the passenger seat. Earlier, she had blasted the song â€œHijos del Canaveralâ€ (â€œSons of the Sugarcane Fieldâ€), written by Puerto Rican hip-hop star RenÃ© PÃ©rez as an ode to Puerto Rico and its peopleâ€™s bravery.

â€œI needed a shot of patriotism,â€ she said. â€œI needed strength to do this once again.â€

Veguilla had waited in line Tuesday, only to be told that the water had run out and that another truck would not be available until Wednesday.

Advertisement
Some people ahead of Veguilla gave up and drove away, with tensions running high the longer people waited.

â€œMove!â€ yelled one driver, fearful of people trying to cut in.

Some who saw the line opted instead to drive to a nearby highway where fresh water trickled down the mountainside via a bamboo pipe that someone had installed.

Greg Reyes, an English teacher, stood in line in muddy flip-flops to collect water for himself, his girlfriend and their cat. He had brought a large bag holding all the empty containers he could find in their house, including more than a dozen small water bottles.

Advertisement
Reyes said he and his partner had been buying water since Fiona hit, but couldnâ€™t afford to do so any longer.

Standing behind him was retiree William RodrÃ­guez, surrounded by three large buckets and four gallon containers. He had been living in Massachusetts and decided to return to Puerto Rico about six months ago.

â€œBut I think Iâ€™m leaving again,â€ he said as he shook his head.

Those in the line grumbled about the slow pace of recovery and accused the government of not helping them as people on social media and even a gym said their doors were open to anyone who needed water or a shower.

Advertisement
â€œThis hasnâ€™t been easy,â€ said Juan Santos, a retiree who held the hand of his 5-year-old grandson. â€œWe are suffering.â€

None of those in line had power either, and many wondered if it would take as long to restore as it did with Hurricane Maria.

Power company officials initially said it would take a few days for electricity to be restored, but then appeared to backtrack Tuesday night, saying they faced numerous obstacles.

Advertisement
â€œHurricane Fiona has severely impacted electrical infrastructure and generation facilities throughout the island. We want to make it very clear that efforts to restore and reenergize continue and are being affected by severe flooding, impassable roads, downed trees, deteriorating equipment, and downed lines,â€ said Luma, the company that operates power transmission and distribution.

Officials said crews found several substations underwater and inaccessible.

But Luma said it expected to restore power Wednesday to much of Puerto Ricoâ€™s north coast, which Fiona largely spared.

The hum of generators could be heard across the territory as people became increasingly exasperated.

â€œI continue to hope that by the end of today, a large part of the population will have these services,â€ said Puerto Rico Gov. Pedro Pierluisi.

Advertisement
The head of the Federal Emergency Management Agency traveled to Puerto Rico on Tuesday and the agency announced it was sending hundreds of additional personnel to boost local response efforts. On Wednesday, U.S. President Joe Biden approved a major disaster declaration, which would allow for more federal assistance.

Meanwhile, the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services declared a public health emergency in Puerto Rico and deployed a couple of teams to the island.

In the Turks and Caicos Islands, officials reported relatively light damage and no deaths, though the eye of the Category 4 storm passed close to Grand Turk, the small British territoryâ€™s capital island, on Tuesday.

Advertisement
â€œTurks and Caicos had a phenomenal experience over the past 24 hours,â€ said Deputy Gov. Anya Williams. â€œIt certainly came with its share of challenges.â€

Officials said school on Grand Turk would reopen next week.

The Hurricane Center said Fiona had maximum sustained winds of 130 mph (215 kph) late Wednesday. It was centered about 550 miles (885 kilometers) southwest of Bermuda, heading north at 10 mph (17 kph).

Fiona killed a man in the French overseas department of Guadeloupe and two others in Puerto Rico swept away by swollen rivers. Two died in the Dominican Republic: one killed by a falling tree and the other by a falling electric post.

Advertisement
Two additional deaths were reported in Puerto Rico as a result of the blackout: A 70-year-old man burned to death after he tried to fill his running generator with gasoline and a 78-year-old man police say inhaled toxic gases from his generator.
